reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: I’ve spent my life investing in simple, predictable businesses like Coca-Cola, See’s Candies, insurance and railroads. Amazon is a complex mix of e-commerce, cloud computing, logistics algorithms and digital advertising—well outside my circle. When I don’t understand how a business makes money, I steer clear.  
2. Competitive Moat: Yes, Amazon has brand recognition, Prime switching costs and scale in AWS. But its ROE has only topped 15% in 0 of 10 periods and its earnings growth is erratic—down 11.1% over 10 periods. A moat without consistent returns is like a castle on sand.  
3. Management & Capital Allocation: Jeff Bezos has been a visionary, but recent stock issuance dilutes existing owners. No dividends or share buybacks tell me they’re plowing every dollar back into an ever-expanding empire. That’s fine for a founder, but not my style—I want managers who think like owners and return capital when they can’t find better uses.  
4. Financial Health & Consistency: Weak ROE at 2.3%, high debt-to-equity at 2.3, and negative owner earnings of $-856 million scream financial fragility. Inconsistent earnings and no data on liquidity ratios add to the concerns.  
5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: A three-stage DCF delivers a negative intrinsic value (conservative IV of $-6.8 billion) and a margin of safety of –108.8%. I never pay for negatives.  
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: E-commerce and cloud will grow, but so will capital requirements and competitive pressures from Walmart, Microsoft, Google and China’s tech giants. Without consistent profits, it’s a high-wire act.  
7. Comparison to My Portfolio: I’d rather own a wonderful business like Coca-Cola at a fair price than a complex one that’s losing owner earnings. Given my circle of competence, I say no. Better opportunities are waiting where I can clearly see the road ahead and sleep soundly at night.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 2.3%; High debt to equity ratio of 2.3; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -11.1% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 24.5%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (72.3%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
